subject: RE: [junit] Recover from test hangs - tail
msgSnippet: I know we are going off topic here, but please excuse me.  I ve tried a few different tail utilities on windows over the years and the best has to be the one
messageBody:
I know we are going off topic here, but please excuse me. I've tried a
few different tail utilities on windows over the years and the best has
to be the one the GNU one. You can download cygwin which provides a
unix API for windows.

If you install cygwin, http://sources.redhat.com/cygwin/, not only do
you get tail, but also grep, cat, awk, wc and others all invoked from a
bash prompt. Luvvly.

Dave

-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: 15 August 2001 13:29
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Recover from test hangs


Sorry everyone. I attached the tail.exe to the previous post and that
caused some folks' email and virus clients to skip a beat. If anyone is
interested in the tail program (freeware) let me know and I will put it
in
the files section of the group. For those who don't know what tail
is...
This is a windows port of the standard UNIX tail that allows you to
monitor
the end of a file as it is being written. It is useful for log files or
debug files. You can also download it from
<http://www.rhazes.com/cgi-bin/Utilitiy_0.asp>

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, August 15, 2001 8:19 AM
> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Subject: RE: [junit] Recover from test hangs
>
>
> Which JDK are you using? You could also use the
> -Xrunhprof option (I think
> it is only available 1.2.x +). Use the attached tail.exe
> to tail the file.
> See
> <http://java.sun.com/products/jdk/1.2/docs/guide/jvmpi/jvm
> pi.html#hprof>
> for how to interpret -Xrunhprof, but basically you are looking for
> ThreadStarts that don't have an associated ThreadEnd.
> This will tell you
> where possible hangs are happening.
>
> -Jason
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: David Roussel [mailto:dir@...]
> > Sent: Wednesday, August 15, 2001 5:08 AM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: RE: [junit] Recover from test hangs
> >
> >
> > Run your tests with the text test runner. When
> it's hung do a
> > Ctrl-Break (on unix you have to send a signal, not sure
> > which one).
> > This causes the JVM to do a thread dump. You can see a
> > stack trace of
> > each thread and hopefully find your deadlock.
> >
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Thach Nguyen [mailto:thach@...]
> > Sent: 14 August 2001 18:20
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit] Recover from test hangs
> >
> >
> > Hello,
> >
> > Could someone advice on how to perform recovery from test
> > hangs. Thanks
> > very much.
> >
> > Thach.
> >
